description: Probably from stem of Old English gewrinclod.

entries.meaning: A small furrow, ridge or crease in an otherwise smooth surface.
A line or crease in the skin, especially when caused by age or fatigue.
examples: Spending time out in the sun may cause you to develop wrinkles sooner.

entries.meaning: A fault, imperfection or bug especially in a new system or product; typically, they will need to be ironed out.
examples: Three months later, we're still discovering new wrinkles.

entries.meaning: A twist on something existing; a novel difference.

verbs.description: wrinkle (third-person singular simple present wrinkles, present participle wrinkling, simple past and past participle wrinkled)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To make wrinkles in; to cause to have wrinkles.
examples: Be careful not to wrinkle your dress before we arrive.

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To pucker or become uneven or irregular.
examples: An hour in the tub will cause your fingers to wrinkle.

entries.meaning: (intransitive, of skin) To develop irreversibly wrinkles; to age.
examples: The skin is the substance that wrinkles, shows age, stretches, scars and cuts.
Ther's some weakenes in your brother you wrinkle at
